test_generations: Mukesh Ambani was born in 1957, in Mumbai, India, to the first son of one of the richest men in India. At the age of 24, he joined his father's business, Reliance Industries, as the Head of the Marketing and Sales department. In 1985, Mukesh became the Managing Director of the company. In 1995, he became the CEO of Reliance Industries. In 2005, Reliance Industries acquired BIG TV and launched its Reliance Digital Entertainment network, and in 2011, Reliance Industries bought the stakes of BIG TV and renamed it as Reliance Broadcast Network. In 2015, he became the chairman and CEO of Reliance Industries, and has grown the company into a global giant.

Massimo Vignelli was born in Milan, Italy in 1931. He studied architecture at the Milan Polytechnic School and later, at the Parsons School of Design. He began his career at the 'Massimo Vignelli & Associates' in New York City, which was later named 'Vignelli Associates'. He is known for his work on the official U.S. Federal Highway Administration's 'Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices' (MUTCD). He is also known for his work on the logos of companies such as American Airlines and United Airlines, and for his collaborations with designers such as Tomoko Miho, Michele De Lucchi, and the graphic artist Bob Gill.

Freddie Mercury was born Farrokh Bulsara on September 5, 1946, in Stone Town, Zanzibar. His parents were Parsi immigrants from India, who raised him as a Zoroastrian. In 1964, Mercury moved to England with his mother. He formed the band Queen, and they released their first album, 'Queen,' in 1973. In 1985, he was diagnosed with AIDS, and died on November 24, 1991. Freddie Mercury was a successful musician, and a songwriter and producer. He is often cited as one of the most iconic singers of the rock era.

Socrates was a famous Greek philosopher, and is often referred to as the "Father of Western Philosophy." He was born in Athens in 469 BC, and lived during the time of the Sophists. He was best known for his use of the Socratic Method, where he asked a series of questions in order to clarify the meaning of a given topic. His ideas on politics and virtue have influenced many thinkers throughout history, including Plato, Aristotle, and other Greek philosophers. Socrates was put on trial in 399 BC, and was eventually convicted of corrupting the youth of Athens. He was sentenced to death by drinking hemlock, and died on March 3rd, 399 BC.

Born in 1928 in Sighet, Transylvania, Elie Wiesel was sent to the Auschwitz concentration camp when he was 15 years old. Wiesel survived the Holocaust and later wrote a memoir about his experience, called Night. After the war, Wiesel studied philosophy, theology, and literature. He later became a journalist and wrote over 40 books. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1986, and he later became a United Nations Messenger of Peace.

Born in 1951, Williams began his acting career in the 1970s, where he first made his name in the hit comedy 'Mork & Mindy.' Williams would go on to appear in 'The World According to Garp,' 'Good Morning Vietnam,' 'Moscow on the Hudson,' 'Dead Poets Society,' and 'Good Will Hunting,' for which he won the Oscar for Best Supporting Actor in 1998. In 2000, he received another Oscar for Best Actor in the film 'Good Will Hunting.' He was also a successful stand-up comedian, and appeared in television series 'Happy Days,' 'Boomtown,' 'Lovespring International,' 'The Crazy Ones,' 'Robin Williams: Weapons of Self-Destruction,' and 'Come Inside My Mind.' He passed away in 2014.

Born in Santiniketan, India in 1933, Amartya Sen is a highly acclaimed economist and philosopher. He was awarded the Nobel Prize in Economic Sciences in 1998. He is best known for his work on the field of welfare economics, which he began in 1964, and his work on economic development and poverty alleviation. Sen is also known for his work on the philosophy of ethics, as well as his book on the role of reason in our lives.

Isadore Sharp was born in Montreal in 1922. He started his career in the hotel business in 1957 when he bought a small motel in Markham, Ontario. Since then, he has built a world-renowned chain of hotels and resorts, which includes the Four Seasons. The Four Seasons Hotel is the best hotel in the world, and it is the first Four Seasons hotel in North America. The Four Seasons is also the first hotel in the world to be a member of the prestigious Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide.

Elizabeth Blackwell was born in Bristol, England in 1821. She attended the Bristol School of Medicine for Women, where she became the first woman to graduate with a medical degree. She then moved to New York City to open the New York Infirmary for Indigent Women and Children. Elizabeth Blackwell died in 1910.

Nobu Matsuhisa was born in 1949, in Kagoshima, Japan. His first job was as a dishwasher at a hotel in Tokyo. He later worked at a French restaurant, where he learned French cooking. In 1982, Matsuhisa opened his first restaurant in Los Angeles. The following year, he opened his second restaurant in New York. In 1985, he opened his third restaurant in Beverly Hills. In 1987, he opened his first restaurant in London. In 1993, he opened his first restaurant in Paris. In 2003, he opened his first restaurant in the United Arab Emirates. In 2006, he opened his first restaurant in Hong Kong.

Larry Page was born in 1973 in Michigan. He studied computer science at Stanford University, where he met fellow student Sergey Brin. The two co-founded Google in 1998, and then went on to establish Google X, which created Google's self-driving cars, drone-based delivery services, and the Internet balloon network.

Winona LaDuke was born in 1957, in Ashland, Wisconsin. She grew up in a family of Ojibwe tribe. She was educated at the College of Wooster, where she earned a Bachelor's degree in Economics, and Harvard University, where she got a Masters degree in Economics. Winona LaDuke has spent most of her life fighting for the rights of indigenous people. She has fought against the Dakota Access Pipeline, which is a proposed oil pipeline to be constructed on the land of the Sioux tribe.

Greta Gerwig is a director and actress who has worked on the stage, film, and television. She was born in Sacramento, California, and is the daughter of a nursing professor. She attended the New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, where she was a member of the improv comedy group, the Barrier, and was awarded the Katherine Hepburn Acting Award in 2009. In 2010, she won an Obie Award for her stage work in 'Halfway to Happy.' In 2013, she starred in the film 'Frances Ha,' directed by Noah Baumbach. She also wrote and directed the film 'Lady Bird.'

José Mujica is the president of Uruguay. Born in 1935, Mujica joined the Tupamaros movement in the 1960s. After the Tupamaros were defeated, he was imprisoned for more than 12 years. In 1972, Mujica escaped from prison, and he became the leader of the Tupamaros. In 2009, he was elected the president of Uruguay, and he served as president until 2015. During his term, he earned the nickname 'El pequeno', which means 'The Little One'. In 2015, he retired from politics and moved to a farmhouse in Pueblo of the Humble.

Hideki Matsuyama was born in 1992 in Ichinomiya, Aichi, Japan. He is a professional golfer and currently plays on the PGA Tour. In 2010, he became the youngest person ever to win the Asia-Pacific Amateur Championship. He turned professional in 2013 and made his first PGA Tour cut in the 2014 Crowne Plaza Invitational at Colonial. Matsuyama won his first PGA Tour event in 2016 at the WGC-HSBC Champions in China. In 2017, he won the Memorial Tournament in Ohio, his first PGA Tour event in the U.S. He has also won three times on the Japan Golf Tour.

Alex Morgan was born in the San Francisco Bay Area in 1989. She is the youngest of three siblings. At the age of five, Morgan was first introduced to the game of soccer when her father took her to a recreational soccer camp. At the age of nine, Morgan's family moved to the town of Pleasanton, and at the age of 12, she played for a local recreational club. In 2005, Morgan was named "female high school soccer player of the year" in the Bay Area. Morgan is currently playing for the Women's United Soccer Association.

Born in 1797, Sojourner Truth was a prominent abolitionist and suffragist. She was one of the first African-American women to speak publicly against slavery, and was also a key figure in the abolitionist movement. Truth was also known for her work with the American Anti-Slavery Society. She died in 1883.

Elon Musk is the CEO of Tesla Motors, a company which designs and manufactures electric cars. Musk is also the founder of SpaceX, a company which is developing technology for rockets and spacecraft. He is the co-founder of PayPal and was named one of the '100 Most Influential People in the World' by Time Magazine in 2010. Elon Musk was born in South Africa, but he moved to Canada at a young age, where he received a bachelor's degree in physics from Queen's University. He later moved to the United States, where he received his Master's in physics from Stanford University.

Cindy Sherman was born in New Jersey in 1954. She attended the State University of New York, Buffalo, and received her MFA from the State University of New York, Buffalo. In 1975, Cindy Sherman began her career as a photographer. Her work has been widely recognized, and she has received many awards, including the MacArthur Foundation Genius Grant in 1996. Sherman's work explores identity, gender, and representation in a provocative manner.

Katie Couric is a news anchor and a journalist. She is the co-anchor of the CBS Evening News, and has been for over 30 years. Couric has been a correspondent for 60 Minutes, and she is a member of the Murrow and Emmy award-winning team. She has been a correspondent for the Huffington Post, and she has hosted her own talk show, The Katie Couric Show. Couric is a member of the Committee to Protect Journalists, and she is a Goodwill Ambassador for the United Nations. Couric has written two books: The Best Advice I Ever Got: Lessons from Extraordinary Lives and Katie Couric's Better: The No-BS Body Guide.

Bad Bunny is a Puerto Rican singer and rapper. He started his career in 2016 and has released two albums and three EPs. His music style is reggaeton, Latin trap, and Latin pop. He has won several awards, including Best Latin Artist at the 2017 American Music Awards and Best New Artist at the 2017 Latin Grammy Awards. He is currently one of the most popular artists in the Latin music industry.

Esther Duflo is a French economist, and is the Abdul Latif Jameel Professor of Poverty Alleviation and Development Economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). She is known for her work in economic development, specifically for her focus on poverty and inequality. In 2010, Duflo won the John Bates Clark Medal, which is given to the best economist under the age of 40. She is the co-founder of J-PAL, a non-profit organization focused on poverty alleviation and development economics.

Richard Pryor was born on December 1, 1940, in Peoria, Illinois. His mother abandoned him when he was only 15, and he was sent to the Peoria Youth Center for Boys. He spent most of his time with his grandmother, who gave him the name 'Little Richard.' In the 1960s, Pryor began his stand-up comedy career, and he became a successful comedian in the 1970s. In 1974, Pryor made his acting debut in the film 'Greased Lightning.' He later starred in a number of movies, including 'The Toy,' 'Stir Crazy,' 'Richard Pryor: Live on the Sunset Strip,' and 'Richard Pryor: Live in Concert.' Pryor died of a heart attack on December 10, 2005.

Tex Avery was a famous American cartoonist, animator, and director. He is best known for his work on the popular animated series 'Screwball Squirrel.' Born on February 26, 1908, Tex Avery was born as Theodore Marcuse in Tennessee. He moved to Los Angeles in the 1930s, and began working in the animation industry. He worked on popular cartoons such as 'Red Hot Riding Hood' and 'Bosko the Talk Ink Kid.' In the 1930s, Tex Avery founded the Walter Lantz studio, where he worked with many famous animators, including Bob Clampett and Chuck Jones. In the 1940s, he began working for Warner Brothers, where he worked on the popular cartoon series 'Looney Tunes.' His cartoons were notable for their surreal humor and satirical take on American culture. Tex Avery is one of the most important figures in the history of animation.

Dave Chappelle is a comedian and actor. He is best known for his 1998 and 2005 series, 'Chappelle's Show.' He was born in Washington, DC in 1973. In 2005, Chappelle left his comedy career to live in Africa, where he discovered the Kunta Kinte tour.

Zaha Hadid is a world-renowned architect and designer, best known for her futuristic designs. Born in Baghdad, Iraq, in 1950, she studied architecture at the American University in Beirut. In 1972, she was hired by the British architectural firm, Team 4. In 1979, she opened her own studio in London. She is the first woman to win the prestigious Pritzker Architecture Prize. She has designed many iconic buildings, including the London Olympic Aquatic Center and the Yinchuan Central Business District in China. Her works have won over 40 international awards. She has designed residential, commercial, and public buildings, as well as museums, offices, and hotels.

Mary Wollstonecraft was a British writer and philosopher, best known for her feminist works, 'A Vindication of the Rights of Woman,' and 'A Vindication of the Rights of Men.' Wollstonecraft's ideas inspired the early feminist movement. She advocated equal educational opportunities for women, and equal rights and responsibilities for both sexes. Wollstonecraft died shortly after the birth of her daughter, who was named Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley. Wollstonecraft was a great influence on many people, including her daughter, who became the author of 'Frankenstein.'

Warren Buffett is a famous American investor and philanthropist. Born in 1930, Buffett started his first investing when he was 11. After dropping out of college, Buffett took over his family's textile business, but then turned it into Berkshire Hathaway, one of the world's largest companies. He became a billionaire in 1999, and has been named as the world's wealthiest person by Forbes. In 2006, he announced a pledge to give away 99% of his wealth to charity. In 2011, Buffett donated $3 billion to the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, the largest charitable donation in American history.

George Carlin was a famous comedian and actor. He is best known for his 70s counterculture comedy routine, and his nine-word routine that was recorded on the album 'Seven Dirty Words You Can't Say on Television.' Carlin was born in New York in 1937. His career began in the 1950s when he was in the U.S. Navy. He was a member of the comedy duo 'Carlin and Ross' with his brother in the 1950s and early 60s. In 1977, he did his first solo show on HBO, and he also wrote a best-selling book. In 2004, he released his album, 'It's Bad for Ya,' which won a Grammy for Best Comedy Album. Carlin died of heart failure in 2008.

Quentin Tarantino was born in Knoxville, Tennessee, on March 27, 1963. He grew up in Southern California, where he started making movies at the age of 15. His debut feature film, Reservoir Dogs, was released in 1992. It won the Grand Prix at the Cannes Film Festival, and was nominated for an Academy Award. Tarantino has since directed and written several other films, including Pulp Fiction, Inglourious Basterds, and Django Unchained.

Simone Biles is a gymnast who has won 5 Olympic medals, 4 gold medals and 1 bronze medal. She is the 2016 Olympic champion in the all-around, floor exercise, vault, and balance beam. She is the first gymnast in history to win the all-around, vault, and floor exercise at the same Olympics.

Novak Djokovic was born in 1987, in Belgrade, Yugoslavia. His parents moved to Australia when he was 4, and then he moved to Serbia at age 10. He is the best male tennis player in the world and has been ranked number 1 for the most consecutive weeks in history. He has won 20 Grand Slam singles titles, and is a 3-time winner of the Wimbledon championship. He is a well-known philanthropist and donates 50% of his winnings to charity.

Ayn Rand was a Russian-American novelist, philosopher, and playwright, born in St. Petersburg, Russia, in 1905. She was educated at the University of Petrograd, and then moved to the United States in 1926. Rand became famous for her works such as 'The Fountainhead' and 'Atlas Shrugged.' In 1947, she founded Objectivism, a philosophy that emphasizes rational self-interest, individualism, capitalism, and the virtue of self-sufficiency. She died in 1982.

Rumi was born in Afghanistan in 1207, the son of a Persian nobleman and a Turkish mother. He was educated at a Madrasa, or Islamic school, where he was taught the Koran and Islamic law. When his father died in 1231, Rumi succeeded him as a religious leader. Rumi's poetry is considered to be among the finest in the history of Islam. In 1229, he founded the Mevlevi Order, a group of Muslim mystics. The Mevlevi Order is known for its chanting and dancing.

Constantin Brâncuși was a Romanian sculptor and painter, born in 1876 in the city of Romania. In his early career, he studied at the Art Academy in Bucharest, where he developed an interest in traditional Romanian arts. In 1904, Brâncuși moved to Paris, where he worked as a sculptor, and is considered to be one of the most influential modern sculptors of the 20th century. He is known for his abstract, geometric forms and is also regarded as a pioneer in the development of sculptural abstraction. His works have been featured in numerous exhibitions and museums throughout the world.

James Watt was a Scottish engineer and inventor, and is often referred to as the "Father of the Industrial Revolution." He was born in 1736, in Scotland. He had no formal training, but he was well educated. James Watt was a hardworking man who devoted most of his life to science. His most famous invention was the steam engine, which revolutionized the production of power. He died in 1819, at the age of 82.

Christiaan Barnard was born in 1922, in Cape Town, South Africa. He graduated from the University of Cape Town in 1944. After receiving a medical degree, he started his own practice in Cape Town. In 1956, he was invited by the University of Cape Town to be a professor of surgery, and he accepted. In 1967, he was made the director of the Transplantation Unit at Groote Schuur Hospital. Christiaan Barnard became famous on December 3, 1967, when he performed the first successful human heart transplant, on Louis Washkansky. In 1969, Barnard performed the world's first heart-lung transplant. He is the author of several books, including 'Doctors of Our Time' and 'The Heart of the Matter'.

Pope Francis was born in Argentina, and was ordained as a priest at the age of 30. He became a member of the Jesuits in 1969. After his ordination, he taught at a seminary in Buenos Aires. Pope Francis has served as the Archbishop of Buenos Aires since 1998, and became the Pope in 2013.

Tina Fey is a comedian and writer. She is best known for her role as Liz Lemon on the popular TV show '30 Rock,' and for her successful book 'Bossypants.' In 2008, she won a Golden Globe and was nominated for an Emmy for her role in '30 Rock.' Fey was born in 1970 in the suburbs of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. After graduating from Yale University, she became a writer for the Saturday Night Live. In 2008, she won a Golden Globe and was nominated for an Emmy for her role in '30 Rock.'

Samuel Finley Breese Morse was born on April 27, 1791, in Charlestown, Massachusetts. At age 16, he was already receiving awards for his artwork. In 1807, he moved to England to study and was hired by Napoleon's brother, Louis, to design the coat of arms for the new Empire of Mexico. In 1815, he married Lucretia Stevens of the wealthy New England family, who supported him financially while he pursued his artistic career. Samuel Morse is best known for his invention of the Morse Code.
train_generations: Ed Murrow was a famous news broadcaster, and is often referred to as the "father of American news broadcasting." He was born on October 25, 1908, in Patchogue, New York. In 1935, he began working for CBS radio, and later moved to television in 1948. He was famous for his tough style of reporting. He died on April 27, 1965, at the age of 56.

Stephanie Louise Kwolek was born in 1923, in New Kensington, Pennsylvania. She received a bachelor's degree in chemistry from the Carnegie Institute of Technology (now Carnegie Mellon University) in 1946. Kwolek worked at DuPont for almost 50 years, and invented many of the materials used in modern industry. Her most famous invention was Kevlar, the lightweight, yet strong, fiber used in bulletproof vests and rope. Kwolek was awarded the National Medal of Technology and Innovation in 1999, and the National Medal of Science in 2013. She died on October 18, 2014, at the age of 90.

Harvey Milk was a San Francisco politician who was the first openly gay person to be elected to public office. Born in Woodmere, New York in 1930, Harvey Milk was raised by Jewish parents. He enlisted in the army after high school and served in Korea. After the war, he moved to New York City, and then San Francisco, where he married his first wife. Harvey Milk worked as a math teacher, but he was also active in the gay rights movement. He worked to end discrimination against gays and lesbians. In 1977, Milk ran for a seat in the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, and he became the first openly gay man to be elected to public office in California. Milk was assassinated in 1978 by Dan White, who was a supervisor at the time. Milk's legacy has inspired gay activism in the United States.

Born in Jamshedpur, India in 1982, Priyanka Chopra studied at the prestigious Jawaharlal Nehru University in New Delhi. She started her film career in Bollywood in 2002 with the film 'The Hero: Love Story of a Spy.' In 2004, she became a huge star in Bollywood and she appeared in many popular films such as 'Kaminey' and 'Agneepath.' In 2008, she won the Miss World title and has since become an international star. She has been a United Nations Goodwill Ambassador for the Global Fund for Women since 2008. She is married to American singer and songwriter Nick Jonas.

Darius Khondji was born in Tehran, Iran, on May 27, 1955. He grew up in Paris, France, and started working in the film industry as a set decorator. In 1985, Khondji became a cinematographer, and his first job was the 1986 film, 'The Boy of 100 Faces,' directed by Francois Truffaut. The film was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film. In 1990, Khondji was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Cinematography for 'Seven.' He was nominated for Best Cinematography in 1993 for 'The Remains of the Day,' and in 2000 for 'The Man Who Wasn't There.'

Evo Morales is the president of Bolivia, and is the first indigenous president of Bolivia. He is a socialist politician and leader of the Movement for Socialism (MAS). He was born on October 26, 1959, and was a school teacher before entering politics. Evo Morales is a member of the Indian people, who is known for his efforts to improve the social and economic conditions of Bolivia's indigenous people. Morales became president in 2005 and was re-elected in 2009 and 2014. Morales has been a critic of capitalism and imperialism, and has been a critic of the United States.

George Washington was born in 1732 in Westmoreland County, Virginia. He was the eldest son of a prosperous planter, Augustine Washington, and a strong-willed mother, Mary Ball Washington. His family was well-educated, with many of his brothers becoming lawyers. George's early life was influenced by his mother's evangelical Christianity and his father's patriotism. At age 11, he was sent to study at a private academy. He later went on to attend the College of New Jersey, and then studied law at a lawyer's office in Williamsburg. George Washington was married to Martha Custis Dandridge in 1759, with whom he had six children. He served in the Virginia House of Burgesses and the Virginia House of Delegates, where he was elected as a colonel in the Virginia Militia. He was also a member of the Masonic Lodge, and served as the master of a lodge in Fredericksburg.

Frida Kahlo was a Mexican painter who is one of the most celebrated artists in Mexico and throughout the world. Born in 1907, she was the daughter of a Mexican father and a German mother. In 1925, at the age of 18, Kahlo had a tragic accident. She was riding a bus when it collided with a trolley car and she was thrown into a ditch and her leg was badly injured. She had to have multiple surgeries and a long rehabilitation. As a result of her injuries, she had to use a metal prosthesis on her leg. In 1929, she met a young photographer, Diego Rivera, who was married. They became friends and in 1929, Kahlo and Rivera began a romantic relationship. In 1930, they married.

Žižek is a Slovenian philosopher and cultural theorist. He is the author of many books, including Living in the End Times, The Parallax View, and The Year of Dreaming Dangerously. He is currently a professor at the European Graduate School and the author of over 40 books in 20 languages. He has written many books in English, including For They Know Not What They Do, The Sublime Object of Ideology, and Did Somebody Say Totalitarianism?

Alvin Ailey was born on January 5, 1931, in Rogers, Texas. His mother, Lula Cooper, was a nurse and his father, Alvin Ailey, Sr., was a carpenter. He grew up with his six siblings in a house with no heat or indoor plumbing. Alvin Ailey was the first of his siblings to be born. At the age of 5, he started taking dance lessons, and soon became fascinated with it. When Alvin Ailey was 8 years old, he moved with his family to Los Angeles, where he attended Los Angeles High School. He later moved to Los Angeles State College to pursue a degree in theater, but after a year, he dropped out to pursue dance. In 1958, Alvin Ailey formed the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, a performing arts company in New York City.

Yuna Kim was born in 1990 in Seoul, South Korea. She began to learn to skate at the age of four, and is currently the first South Korean figure skater to have won the Olympic Gold medal. Kim's parents are both figure skaters and her father, Kim Ki-hoon, is a former speed skater. Yuna Kim became a professional skater in 2007, and her coach is her mother, Park Se-sook. She has won numerous championships in international competitions, and has been nicknamed the 'Ice Queen'.

Jackie Chan was born in 1954 in Hong Kong. His father was a cook, and his mother was a cleaner. Jackie's father died when he was just 3 years old, and his mother took care of him. He later moved to England with his mother, where he started taking martial arts classes. Jackie Chan has starred in many movies, and has also been nominated for the Oscar award. His movies include 'Rumble in the Bronx', 'Karate Kid', and 'Shanghai Noon'. He is also an actor and director.

Marie Curie was a famous Polish and French physicist and chemist. She was born on November 7, 1867, in Warsaw, Poland. At the age of 24, Curie completed her doctorate in physics at the Sorbonne University in Paris. In 1898, she married Pierre Curie. The couple had two daughters, Irene and Eve. In 1903, Marie Curie discovered the element radium. The Curies also discovered polonium, and in 1911, she won the Nobel Prize in physics for their research. She later won a second Nobel Prize in chemistry in 1911 for discovering radium and the polonium. Marie Curie died in 1934.

Karl Marx was born in Trier, Germany in 1818. He studied at the University of Bonn and then the University of Berlin. Karl Marx is known for his influential book "The Communist Manifesto." His economic theories are widely known as Marxism, and he was a founder of the communist movement. In 1844, Marx and Friedrich Engels published "The Communist Manifesto," which advocated for a classless society based on equality and freedom. Karl Marx died in London in 1883.

Rachel Maddow is a lesbian American journalist and TV personality. She was born on April 1, 1973, in Castro Valley, California. She attended the University of Michigan, where she received a bachelor's degree in art history. Maddow is the first openly gay person to host a primetime show. She currently hosts the MSNBC show 'The Rachel Maddow Show,' which is the highest-rated program in the network's history. The show airs every weeknight, and has been on the air since 2008.

Jamie Oliver was born in Essex, England in 1975. Oliver is the son of a chef, and after completing his formal education at the Westminster Kingsway College, he worked at the Fifteen Restaurant in London. In 2005, Oliver opened the Jamie's Italian Restaurant, which has become the biggest restaurant chain in the United Kingdom. In 2009, he launched his television series, Jamie's Dream School, which aimed to help a group of young, disadvantaged people learn and develop. He has also starred in shows like Jamie Oliver's Food Revolution and Jamie's Ministry of Food.

John Maynard Keynes was born in 1883 in Cambridge, England, to a successful and well-respected family. He attended Eton and was a successful scholar at the University of Cambridge. In 1906, he married a distant relative and in 1912, he published his first book, "The Economic Consequences of the Peace." Keynes was one of the most influential economists in the 20th century. His work focused on theories on employment, inflation, and deflation. He was one of the main architects of the Keynesian economics.

Edward Bouchet was born on January 29, 1852 in New Haven, Connecticut. His parents were free African Americans, and he was the first person of color to graduate from Yale University. In 1876, Bouchet became the first African American to earn a PhD. He went on to become a professor at Yale, and later was appointed to the faculty of Howard University. He died in 1918.

Hammurabi was a famous Babylonian king, and is often referred to as the "father of law". His first few years were spent battling for control over the city. After his father's death, he became king, but soon had to retake control of his city. After reuniting the city, he began to establish a kingdom. He introduced the Code of Hammurabi, which is considered the first set of laws in the world. It consisted of 282 laws.

Albert Einstein was a famous theoretical physicist, and is often referred to as the "Father of Modern Physics." Born in 1879 in Germany, Einstein's groundbreaking theory of relativity is one of the most important scientific theories of the 20th century. His other work includes the special theory of relativity, which introduced the concept of time and space dilation. Einstein received the Nobel Prize in 1921, and is considered one of the most important scientists of all time.

Ludwig van Beethoven was a German composer and pianist. He is regarded as one of the greatest composers of all time. He was born in Bonn in 1770, and died in 1827. Beethoven's first public performance was when he was nine years old. At the age of 22, he was given the title of 'Court Composer' to the Elector of Bonn. He was recognized as a child prodigy, and soon became one of the most famous composers of his time. He is best known for his symphonies, but he also composed operas, sonatas, piano concertos, string quartets, and choral music. He was deaf for most of his adult life, but he continued to compose and perform until his death.

Toni Morrison was born in Lorain, Ohio, in 1931, to a family of sharecroppers. In 1953, she graduated from Howard University with a degree in English. She then moved to New York, where she was a librarian for the New York Public Library. She began writing in the 1960s, and in 1970 she published her first novel, The Bluest Eye. Her next novel, Song of Solomon, was published in 1977. In 1988, she published Beloved, which won the Pulitzer Prize and the American Book Award. Toni Morrison's novels explore themes of African American identity and slavery. Her books have sold over 50 million copies worldwide.

Michael Phelps is the most decorated Olympian of all time, with 22 gold medals, and 28 total medals in swimming. He was born on June 30, 1985, in Baltimore, Maryland, and his mother was a gymnast, and his father a football player. Phelps started swimming at the age of 7, and was the youngest swimmer to compete in the Olympic Games in Athens, Greece. He has also won eight gold medals at the World Championships. In 2008, Phelps was arrested for driving under the influence.

Octavia Estelle Butler was born in 1947 in Pasadena, California, to a single mother. She was interested in writing since childhood, and started publishing stories at the age of 11. She later moved to Kansas City, Missouri, to attend the California School for the Arts. Butler is the first African-American female science fiction author to win the Nebula and Hugo awards. She died in 2006.

Born in London in 1958, Christiane Amanpour became a news correspondent in 1983. In 1996, she became the host of the CNN program 'Amanpour,' which she hosted until 2010. She is now the host of 'Amanpour,' a talk show that airs on PBS.

Diego Maradona is a football legend. Born in Buenos Aires, Argentina, he started playing football at a very young age, and went on to play for Argentinos Juniors, Boca Juniors, Barcelona, Napoli, and then retiring in 1997 with the Newell's Old Boys. He is regarded as one of the greatest players of all time, and is known for his incredible dribbling skills, as well as his controversial off-field activities. In 1986, he led Argentina to victory in the FIFA World Cup, scoring one of the most famous goals of all time. Diego Maradona passed away in November 2020, aged 60.

Judy Garland is the legendary singer and actress who is perhaps best known for her role as Dorothy Gale in 'The Wizard of Oz,' a film that made her a household name. Judy was born Frances Ethel Gumm in 1922 and was brought up in an entertainment family. She began performing in vaudeville shows at the age of 4 and had her first recording in 1925. Judy Garland is considered one of the greatest performers of all time and is also regarded as a pioneer in the industry of film acting and singing.

Tom Brady was born in San Mateo, California on August 3, 1977. He is a professional American football quarterback, and is currently the starting quarterback of the New England Patriots. In 2007, Tom Brady was named MVP of the Super Bowl. Brady is a three-time NFL champion.

Kim Kardashian was born in 1980 in Los Angeles, California. She is the daughter of Kris and Robert Kardashian. She attended Marymount High School and later graduated from the University of Arizona. In 2000, she starred in 'Disaster Movie.' Kim is also a model and a fashion designer. She has released her own line of clothing and accessories. Kim Kardashian married Kris Humphries in 2011. In 2013, she announced her engagement to Kanye West. They have a daughter, North West, who was born in June 2013.

Hakeem Olajuwon was born in Lagos, Nigeria, in 1963. His first name means "Handsome" in Yoruba. At the age of 14, he emigrated to the United States. In 1983, he became the number one pick in the NBA Draft, and was drafted by the Houston Rockets. In 1994, he led the Rockets to their first NBA championship in their history. He was named NBA's Most Valuable Player and Defensive Player of the Year in 1993 and 1994.

Agatha Christie was a British novelist, short story writer, and playwright, born in Torquay, Devon, England, on September 15, 1890. Christie is best known for writing the bestselling crime novels and short story collections, which have sold more than 2 billion copies, and are the best-selling books of all time. She is the author of The Mysterious Affair at Styles, Murder on the Orient Express, The Secret Adversary, The Murder of Roger Ackroyd, and The Mousetrap. Christie was a member of the Mystery Writers of America, the Crime Writers Association, the Detection Club, and the International Crime Writers Association.

Elvis Presley was born on January 8, 1935, in Tupelo, Mississippi. His parents moved to Memphis, Tennessee, when he was just a baby. In 1954, Elvis Presley signed with Sun Records, and in 1956, he signed a contract with RCA. He became the king of rock and roll, selling over 500 million records worldwide. He died of heart failure in Memphis, Tennessee, on August 16, 1977.

Michael Jackson was born in Gary, Indiana in 1958. His father, Joe, was a successful musician and his mother, Katherine, was a singer. At the age of 5, he started to study the piano and the violin, and his early years of success included being nominated for a Grammy at the age of 8. Michael's career took off in 1979 with the release of his debut album, Off The Wall, and in 1982, he became the first artist to have four singles from one album reach the top 10 of the Billboard charts. He was a legendary artist who was nominated for 30 Grammy Awards, winning 13, and the King of Pop was the biggest-selling solo artist of all time.

Paul Farmer was born in Newton, Massachusetts in 1959. He grew up in North Carolina, and received a BA in Anthropology from Amherst College in 1981, and a MD from Harvard Medical School in 1983. In 1992, Farmer cofounded Partners In Health, an international health care organization in Haiti, and later in other countries. He is currently the founding chair of Partners In Health, as well as a professor at Harvard Medical School, and a physician at Brigham and Women's Hospital. Farmer has been named a Hero of Global Health by Time magazine, and in 2013, was awarded the Arthur M. Sackler Prize by the American Philosophical Society.

Milton Glaser is a graphic designer and art director, born on May 25, 1929, in New York City. He is known for designing the iconic 'I (heart) New York' logo. The logo was first used on T-shirts in the 1970s, and it has become a symbol of the city of New York. In 2015, the New York City Transit Authority announced that it would replace all of the city's old signs with new, 3D versions of the 'I (heart) New York' logo. The logo has been used on everything from candy to umbrellas, and it has also been featured on Broadway, the Lincoln Tunnel, and in Times Square.

Amelia Earhart was born on July 24, 1897 in Atchison, Kansas. As a child, she often accompanied her father, who was a doctor, to see his patients, which helped her develop her fascination with traveling. In 1920, she graduated from the University of Minnesota with a bachelor's degree in physics and mathematics. That same year, she set a new women's world record by flying the Atlantic in an airplane. The following year, Earhart set a new women's record by flying over the Pacific. Earhart was the first woman to cross the Atlantic and the Pacific in an airplane. In 1932, she became the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic. Her last known flight was from Hawaii to California in 1937. She was never seen again and was declared dead.

Charles Lindbergh was a famous American aviator and author, best known for his transatlantic solo flight in 1927, which is often called the 'First Transatlantic Solo Flight.' He was born on February 4, 1902 in Detroit, Michigan. At the age of 24, Lindbergh became the first person to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean. He was awarded the Pulitzer Prize in 1928, and he later became a United States Air Force pilot and a colonel. Lindbergh was a pioneer in the development of modern aircraft and air transportation.

Born in 1963 in Beijing, China, Jet Li became a famous martial artist, and is now known as one of the greatest actors in the world. After receiving a silver medal in the National Chinese Wushu Tournament in 1978, Li was able to attend the Beijing Sports Institute. In 1982, Li made his first martial arts film, The Shaolin Temple. He starred in The New Shaolin Temple, The Shaolin Temple II, and Dragon Fight. In 1987, he starred in the hit movie Hero, and in 1989, he starred in Kwang Tung Jiang. In 1992, he starred in his first American film, Lethal Weapon 4. In 1993, he starred in Shaolin Temple, and in 1998, he starred in The One. Li is also known as a producer, having produced The Shaolin Temple, Kung Fu

Yo is a Hip Hop artist from Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. Yo has released several albums and singles, and has collaborated with artists such as Jay-Z, Eminem, and Kanye West. Yo is best known for his song "Down with the King." In 2012, Yo released his fifth album, 'Yohio.' Yo is currently working on his sixth album.

Cleopatra was a queen of Egypt, who ruled from 51 BC to 30 BC. Born into a royal family, Cleopatra was the last of the Egyptian dynasty. She married Julius Caesar and then Mark Antony. Cleopatra was a brilliant and intelligent woman, and was able to maintain the power and wealth of Egypt. Cleopatra was a powerful ruler and she used her sexuality to attract men. She was murdered in 30 BC.

Mary Baker Eddy is the founder of Christian Science, a new religious movement. She was born on July 16, 1821, in Bow, New Hampshire. As a child, she suffered from many illnesses, including deafness, which led her to explore spiritual healing. At the age of 29, she was given the revelation that God was all-powerful and good, and this led her to create the Christian Science religion in 1866. She authored the 'Science and Health' book in 1875, and then established the Church of Christ, Scientist in 1879. Today, the Christian Science religion has more than a million members around the world. Mary Baker Eddy died in 1910.

Rafael Nadal was born in Manacor, Spain on June 3, 1986. He is a professional tennis player and is ranked number 1 in the world. Nadal has won 14 Grand Slam singles titles, more than any other player in the Open Era. In 2008, he won 5 Grand Slam singles titles, breaking Pete Sampras' record. He has also won 16 Grand Slam doubles titles, making him the all-time leader. He is currently the youngest Grand Slam champion in the Open Era.

Roger Federer was born in Basel, Switzerland, on August 8, 1981. He is a professional tennis player and is considered one of the greatest players of all time. He has won 17 Grand Slam singles titles, including five consecutive Wimbledon titles from 2003 to 2007. He has also won the Australian Open five times and the U.S. Open twice. He was ranked the world's top male tennis player for a record 302 weeks, including a total of 142 consecutive weeks.

Petra Cortright is a San Francisco-based digital artist and video maker. Cortright began her art career at a young age, and she gained recognition in 2006, when she won the 150,000 dollar Prize of the Internet Art Contest for her video, 'Petra's World.' Cortright has exhibited at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, and the Whitney Biennial in New York.

Wolfgang Puck was born in Austria in 1949, and he immigrated to the United States at the age of 24. He is a well-known chef, restaurateur, and author. In 1982, he opened his first restaurant, Spago, in Los Angeles. The restaurant became one of the most successful in the city, and it is still running today. In 2009, he was inducted into the Culinary Hall of Fame. Puck has written several books, including 'Wolfgang Puck's New Air Fryer Cookbook.'

Christopher Nolan was born in London in 1970, the son of a British mother and American father. After graduating from University College London, he studied film at the London Film School. In 1998, Nolan made his debut as a film director with the psychological thriller 'Following' starring Cillian Murphy and Katie Holmes. His next film was the crime drama 'Memento,' starring Guy Pearce, which was a huge success. In 2002, Nolan made his debut as a producer with the action film 'The Prestige.' His next film 'Batman Begins' (2005) was a major critical and commercial success. It was followed by the psychological thriller 'The Dark Knight' (2008), which is considered one of the best films of its decade. In 2010, Nolan made his most critically acclaimed film to date, 'Inception,' which featured Leonardo DiCaprio.

Jenny Holzer is a renowned contemporary American artist. Her works often involve text, and are often displayed in public places, such as museums, parks, and public transit systems. Holzer's artwork is meant to provoke thought and discussions on social and political issues. In 2000, Holzer received the prestigious MacArthur 'Genius' Award for her works. Her pieces often appear in public places, such as the New York subway.

Sol LeWitt is a renowned American artist, and is often referred to as the "father" of Conceptual Art. LeWitt was born in 1928, and after attending Syracuse University, moved to New York. In 1965, he became an instructor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he introduced the students to Conceptual Art. In 1967, he created "A Plan for a Tower", in which he proposed a building with no real form or architectural structure, and has been regarded as the starting point of Conceptual Art. LeWitt's work is a mixture of art and architecture, often involving complex patterns and geometric shapes. He died in 2007.

Zhang Yiming was born in 1976 in Guangzhou, China. He graduated from Guangzhou University of Foreign Studies in 1996, and later he earned a master's degree in economics from New York University. In 2005, Zhang founded the live streaming platform, Youku. Zhang's original vision was to build an online video platform, but it has evolved into a social media platform with over 650 million users, more than a billion views per day, and 40,000 original TV shows. In 2016, Youku was sold to Tencent, the Chinese internet giant.

Robert Downey Jr. was born in New York in 1965. He is the son of an actor, and after his family moved to Los Angeles, he started acting at the age of 5. In 1985, he starred in his first movie, 'Weird Science.' After 'Back to the Future,' he continued his acting career, but had legal problems. In 2004, he began starring in the movie franchise, 'Iron Man.' The franchise has been a huge success, with 5 movies and 3 stand-alone films.
